body: With only the method in the interface being generic, not the interface itself, there is no way for the compiler to know if the return value of the method in the concrete class conforms to the interface. It doesn't matter if not all methods in the generic interface use the generic type, but putting the type on the interface and the class allows the compiler to see they are the same.

No, It's the OCP certification book of Selikoff and Boyarsky. They state that:   1. The method in the child class must have the same signature as the method in the parent class. 2. The method in the child class must be at least as accessible as the method in the parent class. 3. The method in the child class may not declare a checked exception that is new or broader than the class of any exception declared in the parent class method. 4. If the method returns a value, it must be the same or a subtype of the method in the parent class, known as covariant return types.
The 5 rules that you listed are not really what the language spec says... I'm guessing you are looking for something in the Java Language Specification that documents this?

Static fields and methods do not participate in inheritance. They are associated with their declaring class, and only that class. There is no way to enforce a class define a static field or method (at least not through normal means). If you declare a static field or method in a parent class, and then another field or method in a child class with the same name, the latter hide (not override) the former. Due to type erasure, all generic parameters are replaced with their bound at compile-time, thus, at runtime, only the upper bounds are left. Not the actual types. If no bound is specified, we are left with Object as implicit upper bound.

"where is expected Integer" it's not expecting an Integer. It's just an Object. The fact it "should be" an Integer is supposed to be enforced by compile-time type checking and inserted casts; but these can't be enforced because of the raw type of the variable.

Well, I have a counter point to the statement "But if say T is <T extends Comparable<T>>, then (T[]) new Object[n] would fail." Think of a situation where we implement a data structure like ArrayList<T>. The erasure of T is Object. In our internal implementation, we just keep an Object[]. Now suppose a client of our API, creates an ArrayList<Integer>, given Integer is a Comparable, it would not fail at the casting site. We just convince the compiler. The same holds true if you have an ArrayList<Predicate<String>> et.al. Isn't that so.

"You can either create an Object array and cast it to the generic type you need" It would have to be an array of the erasure of T. If T's erasure is Object, then that would be okay. But if say T is <T extends Comparable<T>>, then (T[]) new Object[n] would fail. You would need (T[]) new Comparable[n] instead, since Comparable is the erasure of T. In the OP's case, they want to create an array of a parameterized type. The erasure of a parameterized type is just the raw type. They should use (Predicate<Integer[]>[])new Predicate[n] and (Consumer<Integer[]>[])new Consumer[n]

@Nyerguds "Java generics are fake, plain and simple." ... the use of strongly judgemental language to describe Java;s type system is not helpful. No, It's the OCP certification book of Selikoff and Boyarsky. They state that:   1. The method in the child class must have the same signature as the method in the parent class. 2. The method in the child class must be at least as accessible as the method in the parent class. 3. The method in the child class may not declare a checked exception that is new or broader than the class of any exception declared in the parent class method. 4. If the method returns a value, it must be the same or a subtype of the method in the parent class, known as covariant return types.
The 5 rules that you listed are not really what the language spec says... I'm guessing you are looking for something in the Java Language Specification that documents this?

Well, I have a counter point to the statement "But if say T is <T extends Comparable<T>>, then (T[]) new Object[n] would fail." Think of a situation where we implement a data structure like ArrayList<T>. The erasure of T is Object. In our internal implementation, we just keep an Object[]. Now suppose a client of our API, creates an ArrayList<Integer>, given Integer is a Comparable, it would not fail at the casting site. We just convince the compiler. The same holds true if you have an ArrayList<Predicate<String>> et.al. Isn't that so.

"You can either create an Object array and cast it to the generic type you need" It would have to be an array of the erasure of T. If T's erasure is Object, then that would be okay. But if say T is <T extends Comparable<T>>, then (T[]) new Object[n] would fail. You would need (T[]) new Comparable[n] instead, since Comparable is the erasure of T. In the OP's case, they want to create an array of a parameterized type. The erasure of a parameterized type is just the raw type. They should use (Predicate<Integer[]>[])new Predicate[n] and (Consumer<Integer[]>[])new Consumer[n]

Well, I have a counter point to the statement "But if say T is <T extends Comparable<T>>, then (T[]) new Object[n] would fail." Think of a situation where we implement a data structure like ArrayList<T>. The erasure of T is Object. In our internal implementation, we just keep an Object[]. Now suppose a client of our API, creates an ArrayList<Integer>, given Integer is a Comparable, it would not fail at the casting site. We just convince the compiler. The same holds true if you have an ArrayList<Predicate<String>> et.al. Isn't that so.

"You can either create an Object array and cast it to the generic type you need" It would have to be an array of the erasure of T. If T's erasure is Object, then that would be okay. But if say T is <T extends Comparable<T>>, then (T[]) new Object[n] would fail. You would need (T[]) new Comparable[n] instead, since Comparable is the erasure of T. In the OP's case, they want to create an array of a parameterized type. The erasure of a parameterized type is just the raw type. They should use (Predicate<Integer[]>[])new Predicate[n] and (Consumer<Integer[]>[])new Consumer[n]

No, It's the OCP certification book of Selikoff and Boyarsky. They state that:   1. The method in the child class must have the same signature as the method in the parent class. 2. The method in the child class must be at least as accessible as the method in the parent class. 3. The method in the child class may not declare a checked exception that is new or broader than the class of any exception declared in the parent class method. 4. If the method returns a value, it must be the same or a subtype of the method in the parent class, known as covariant return types.
The 5 rules that you listed are not really what the language spec says... I'm guessing you are looking for something in the Java Language Specification that documents this?

Due to type erasure, all generic parameters are replaced with their bound at compile-time, thus, at runtime, only the upper bounds are left. Not the actual types. If no bound is specified, we are left with Object as implicit upper bound.

"where is expected Integer" it's not expecting an Integer. It's just an Object. The fact it "should be" an Integer is supposed to be enforced by compile-time type checking and inserted casts; but these can't be enforced because of the raw type of the variable.

@TheophileDano OP wants to invoke Consumer#andThen on a Consumer<Employee> bound to Employee::incrementAge. In effect, OP wants to call forEach(X.andThen(Y)) where X and Y are both method references, but that is simply not valid, because the compiler does not know how to infer the type of the left-hand method reference (X).
In your second code sample, the parentheses are incorrectly placed

In the second example, the type inference engine cannot infer the type of Employee::incrementAge. A method reference does not have a single, inferrable type. Rather, it can be bound to any functional interface with a compatible signature. If the type is not known, then members like andThen cannot be resolved.

Well, I have a counter point to the statement "But if say T is <T extends Comparable<T>>, then (T[]) new Object[n] would fail." Think of a situation where we implement a data structure like ArrayList<T>. The erasure of T is Object. In our internal implementation, we just keep an Object[]. Now suppose a client of our API, creates an ArrayList<Integer>, given Integer is a Comparable, it would not fail at the casting site. We just convince the compiler. The same holds true if you have an ArrayList<Predicate<String>> et.al. Isn't that so.

"You can either create an Object array and cast it to the generic type you need" It would have to be an array of the erasure of T. If T's erasure is Object, then that would be okay. But if say T is <T extends Comparable<T>>, then (T[]) new Object[n] would fail. You would need (T[]) new Comparable[n] instead, since Comparable is the erasure of T. In the OP's case, they want to create an array of a parameterized type. The erasure of a parameterized type is just the raw type. They should use (Predicate<Integer[]>[])new Predicate[n] and (Consumer<Integer[]>[])new Consumer[n]

Well, I have a counter point to the statement "But if say T is <T extends Comparable<T>>, then (T[]) new Object[n] would fail." Think of a situation where we implement a data structure like ArrayList<T>. The erasure of T is Object. In our internal implementation, we just keep an Object[]. Now suppose a client of our API, creates an ArrayList<Integer>, given Integer is a Comparable, it would not fail at the casting site. We just convince the compiler. The same holds true if you have an ArrayList<Predicate<String>> et.al. Isn't that so.

"You can either create an Object array and cast it to the generic type you need" It would have to be an array of the erasure of T. If T's erasure is Object, then that would be okay. But if say T is <T extends Comparable<T>>, then (T[]) new Object[n] would fail. You would need (T[]) new Comparable[n] instead, since Comparable is the erasure of T. In the OP's case, they want to create an array of a parameterized type. The erasure of a parameterized type is just the raw type. They should use (Predicate<Integer[]>[])new Predicate[n] and (Consumer<Integer[]>[])new Consumer[n]
